results.title: Goldfinger
results.creator_credit: Ken Adam, Guy Hamilton, Albert R. Broccoli, Harry Saltzman, United Artists Corporation and Danjaq
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “James Bond”.
In this non-stop action thriller, Sean Connery is Agent 007 and Gert Frobe is the notorious gold smuggler (appropriately named Goldfinger) who has initiated a cataclysmic scheme to raid Fort Knox and obliterate the world economy. James Bond, armed with his specially equipped Aston Martin and devilish good looks, must stop the plan by overcoming several perilous situations and outrageous adversaries, including Oddjob who kills with a toss of his lethal hat, and the sexy pilot, Pussy Galore, whose romantic feelings for Bond complicate her involvement in Goldfinger’s high-flying scheme. Cast includes: Sean Connery, Gert Frobe, Honor Blackman, Shirley Eaton and Bernard Lee as “M”.

results.title: GoldenEye 007
results.brief_description: GoldenEye 007 inspired endless fun when it was released on the Nintendo 64 – just as long as you didn’t look at anyone’s screen or play as Odd Job. One of the first multi-player first-person-shooters for console, GoldenEye made everyone 007.

constellations_other.name: Gunslingers, good fellas and flea bags
constellations_other.description: Explore how a 1903 western changed the course of filmmaking and videogames by breaking the fourth wall.

constellations_other.name: Capturing first-person POV
constellations_other.description: A comparison of how videogames and feature films have used first person POV shots and sequences and how (for the latter) camera technology has impacted on this.

recommendations.quote: There's never been a better adaptation of film into a videogame than Golden Eye. For the first time, up to four players could shoot it out on one TV screen and take control of one of some of cinema's best heroes and villains. And yes, Odd Job is cheating.

results.description: GoldenEye 007 inspired endless fun when it was released on the Nintendo 64 – just as long as you didn’t look at anyone’s screen or play as Odd Job. One of the first multi-player first-person-shooters for console, GoldenEye made everyone 007.
description_for_label: GoldenEye 007 inspired endless fun when it was released on the Nintendo 64 – just as long as you didn’t look at anyone’s screen or play as Odd Job. One of the first multi-player first-person-shooters for console, GoldenEye made everyone 007.

results.title: Goldeneye (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Martin Campbell, Barbara Broccoli, Michael G. Wilson, United Artists Corporation and Danjaq
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “James Bond”.
Pierce Brosnan ignites the screen as the legendary James Bond in this explosive, thrill-packed adventure that hits the bulls-eye for nonstop excitement. When a deadly satellite weapon system falls into the wrong hands, only agent 007 can save the world from certain disaster. Cast includes Sean Bean, Izabella Scorupco and Famke Janssen.

results.title: Goldeneye
results.creator_credit: Martin Campbell, Barbara Broccoli, Michael G. Wilson and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “James Bond”.
When a deadly satellite weapon falls into the wrong hands, only Agent 007 (Pierce Brosnan) can save the world from certain disaster. Armed with his license to kill and his smooth talking ways, Bond races to Russia in search of the stolen access codes for “GoldenEye”, the devastating satellite weapon. James Bond is pitted against an enemy who knows his every movement, a former agent, 006, trained in exactly the same methods and who can anticipate his every move. Alec Trevelyan (Sean Bean), agent 006 is motivated by a hatred that goes back years. 006 is not the only person causing Bond grief, he also battles with his former compatriot’s stunning ally, Xenia Onatopp (Famke Janssen), who crushes victims between her shapely but deadly thighs.

results.title: Golden Twenties
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “March of Time”.
A chronicle of America’s Jazz Age based on a study of the 1920’s by Frederick Lewis Allen and Samuel Wood Bryant. Over 150 famous people appear, including the Prince of Wales, H.G. Wells, Thomas Edison, Woodrow Wilson, Charles Lindbergh and Al Capone. Famous sporting personalities and entertainers are presented including excerpts from feature films of the era starring Rudolp Valentino, Al Jolson and Greta Garbo among others. Edited by Leo Zochling.

results.title: Golden Transvaal
results.creator_credit: John Da Silva and South African Tourist Corporation
results.brief_description: Within the borders of the Transvaal is to be found a wide diversity of attractions, both natural and manmade. These include Johannesburg, historic Pretoria, the flat plains and mountain ranges and the warm sub-tropical Lowveld, and the Kruger National Park.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Da Silva and South African Tourist Corporation

results.title: Golden summers: the Heidelberg school
results.creator_credit: Peter Bramley, Peter Purvis and National Gallery of Victoria
results.brief_description: Golden Summers covers the most celebrated period in the history of Australian art, the years from 1885 until shortly after the turn of the century. The artists at the time were Tom Roberts, Arthur Streeton, Charles Conder and Fred McCubbin, popularly known as the Heidelberg School, and they believed that it was their task to paint Australian realities. Narrated by Patrick McCaughey.

results.title: Golden sands
results.creator_credit: John Martin-Jones, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and John Shaw
results.brief_description: Describes beach mining for minerals - rutile, zircon, ilmenite and monazite - as an important Australian industry. Shows several methods of extracting these minerals and explains many of their uses.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Martin-Jones, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and John Shaw

results.title: Golden river
results.creator_credit: Documentary Films of India and P.V. Pathy
results.brief_description: Rising in the ranges of Coorg, the Kaveri River flows eastwards for nearly 500 miles before entering the Bay of Bengal, traversing ancient agricultural lands, rich in rice and coffee. Traces the course of the Kaveri River which has been considered sacred by the Hindus for centuries. The waters of the river have been utilised for the generation of electic power at Sivasamudram and harnessed in Mysore and Mettur for the two great dams which irrigate thousands of acres of land.
